title: Anyone worried about the rise of J4?
body:
Oh I'm not talking about his Mobility being strong

Or his engage

Or his insane synergy with Gnar

Or his damage:tank ratio

I mean whenever a Jungler tries to challenge a certain monk in that role they errr, they tend to get nerfed pretty hard


in all seriousness if Riot decides to nerf J4 then I say Lee nerfs should come with him, specially since Riot don't see a problem with Lee and the community mostly don't see a problem with J4 (minus Gnarvin but hey that's an effective wombo for you)

replies.body: This shit bothers the ever living hell out of me.  He's not, "On the rise".  He's filling in for the lackluster group of junglers that can perform because Riot can't balance a champion for their lives.  It's the same thing with Tristana; when Pro players thought she was "OP".  No champion is OP, Riot is just forcing other predominant champions that perform at a lower level compared to the recently nerfed champion line, because they nerf for the now and not the later.

normally i would agree with you, but not this time

J4 punishes non-mobile champs extremely hard (you gotta have flash else you can't do anything): we need champs that punish mobility, not the opposite

Azir's ult punishes mobility.

http://st.elohell.net/public/chill/49f7f43c571d0ffd8e81c24fac785d31.gif

Is that really something we should be worried about? I'm worried that because everyone wants to play their favorite champions, they want the ones that can beat them to be nerfed.

I for one hate the "this champion can do more with energy" and "that champion would be to OP if you did this small change". It bewilders me. 

How many times do we see a buff that actually does just damage anymore?

Now, its all about armor pen and magic res. I for one do not think that champion abilities should have to have so much put into them. I say, make Shen have reasonable Energy costs, give mana regen its crazy regen back, undo a lot of nerfs that have been done to fun champions and items, and for the love of God, can word on Ao Shin please reach us, Riot.

I can't even play Zac because he was too strong when HP regen could help him, I want to play Yorick who isn't broken anymore because of item changes, and I want to play the different game modes Riot seems to think we hate because they sure don't stay long. (What I meant was, I want them to stay.)

Look at what Riot did to so many champions because you removed 1 item from the game. Garen wanted to be a Sorcerer, but Riot said no. I don't really understand why it was removed. I never heard of anything bad coming from it, unlike Zhonya's Hourglass which has a lot more troll moves.

I just want to touch on your comment about Shen.  I feel like Shen is the ONE energy champ that is close to the right place.  Energy should be limited, and every energy champ should have to land something to have enough energy to do a full combo, just like Shen has to land his taunt.  (He needs other buffs, I think, but this one aspect is right.)  Zed would be much less oppressive if he had to land either 2 Q's or 2 E's (one from himself and one from his shadow) in order to get energy back to do the other.  This rewards skillful use of the skillshots, and allows counterplay in that dodging stops him from just continuing anyway.  (Hell, I'd even consider making shadow swapping cost energy so he'd have to land those skillshots with both himself and his shadow in order to escape after an ult.)
long live {{champion:85}}
Punishing mobility requires more mobility.  So I don't think that logic is sound.

Champions who have mobility pay for it by giving up some other strength.  (Generally, that is how it is supposed to work.  Of course, Riot's balance team doesn't get it quite right, but the point is the same.  When a champion is designed with mobility, they try to design it with some lack of strength elsewhere.  Xerath lacks mobility and makes up for it with sheer power and two forms of CC.  Zed has lots of mobility and can't CC at all without an item.)

With that in mind, anything that negates mobility, such as Azir's ult, or ignores mobility, such as Vi's ult, essentially lowers the overall strength of the champion.
Zed does have soft CC in the form of a slow, but your point about mobility being a tradeoff (theoretically) is correct.

J4 was my main jungler S3 and my fall back jungler in S4 so I would be positive about J4 and the critique tossing was simply because Lee and J4 do the same thing differently

-Both are highly mobile (lee more so)
-Both have high damage
-Both are good initiators

the literal difference is with a Gnar J4 can supasse Lee's engage with the Gnarvin R combo but unlike Lee who can cause your highest value player to get deleted by himself it takes 2 for J4 to do an equivalent

The difference I see between them is that JIV's mobility comes at the cost of his initiation. It's his only way in, and he doesn't have a way out afterwards. He's mobile while engaging, but otherwise not so much. And his damage? Yeah it's great, but Lee's scalings are so god awful high that he can build a Hydra and keep up in damage output by the numbers while building two tank items while other junglers would have to build two more damage items to beat him out in terms of hurt.

I feel like people who play JIV have to *work* for what they get. I've never really paid attention to the pro scene, as I prefer to learn myself instead of copying others, but I did sit down to watch the season 4 finale and when I saw JIV in action the way he was used I bought him pretty much immediately and since then I've been trying to learn him. He definitely doesn't disappoint, but I've never once felt that I was being fed things. I work for every assist and every kill, and when I die I feel like it's my fault.

2. Tanks are meant to initiate. They are not meant to have escapes.
